title: Reproducible Reports with R Markdown
text:
YAML
---
title: "Document title"
author: "Lewis Forwarder"
output: html_document
---

Starts with ---, ends with ---
Intuitive syntax \(\rightarrow\) field: value
Outputs: HTML, docx, pptx, (pdf)

title: Reproducible Reports with R Markdown
text:
Markdown
Intuitive language to write, in plain text, a document that is transformed into a report (in Rstudio, go to submenu “Help > Markdown Quick Reference” for a quick tour).

Emphasis
*italic*   **bold**
_italic_   __bold__
Headers
# Header 1
## Header 2
### Header 3

Unordered List
* Item 1
* Item 2
    + Item 2a
    + Item 2b

Ordered List
1. Item 1
2. Item 2
3. Item 3
    + Item 3a
    + Item 3b

And so much more!

title: Reproducible Reports with R Markdown
text:
R Chunks
Your code goes in “R chunks”1.



```{r chunk title, echo = TRUE}
hist(rnorm(100))
```











Customization:

Beginners: ⚙️,
Intermediate users: go here,
Advanced users: Yi Hui’s website.


click on “+c” to insert a chunk quickly

title: Reproducible Reports with R Markdown
text:
Other features

PDF: \(\LaTeX\)
Maths: \(\LaTeX\)
Customized HTML documents: CSS (ou SCSS)
Diagrams: mermaid or GraphViz
Other high-level programming languages: Python, Julia, SQL
Other: bash, Rcpp (C++), Stan (Bayesian statistics), etc.

title: Reproducible Reports with R Markdown
text:
Most useful fields

title: title of the document
author: your name
output:

html_document \(\rightarrow\) is the easiest to use
word_document \(\rightarrow\) is very convenient
pdf_document \(\rightarrow\) requires \(\LaTeX\)

create a document,

Click on “Knit”

title: Introduction and Reminders
text:
Schedule, language, etc

Day 1: tips and tricks of dplyr and ggplot2. Create a report in R Markdown.
Day 2: Heatmaps, and other advanced graphical representations. Create panels of plots. Good practices in data visualization.
Day 3: work on your data.

Useful dplyr functions

filter: filter observations
mutate: add, modify, variables
group_by: create groups
summarize: compute summary statistics (on groups)

title: Workshop: reproduce a complex panelled figure
text: In this workshop, you will reproduce Figure 2 from (Ong et al. 2020) (from the cleaned data located here) and write a short report explaining your choices, results, and limitations.

title: About
text:
Amaury et Vincent
We are engineers at the Hub of Bioinformatics and Biostatistics. Link
Please check the schedule for the Open Desk, every Tuesday mornings. Link


We must thank…

STA120, for inspiring us a lot with their beautiful website!
…

title: Workshop: reproduce a complex figure
text: We want to reproduce Figure 2 from (Ong et al. 2020), and create a report to describe the sub-figures of this panel.

title: Workshop: reproduce a complex panelled figure
text:
The Figure
Figure 2 contains three sub-panels:

a clustered heatmap with sample annotations,
longitudinal expression profiles for inflammatory genes,
longitudinal expression profiles for T-cell markers.

title: Workshop: reproduce a complex figure
text:
Detailed intructions
We will create groups of students, work with your group to exchange information.
Start with each subfigure individually to break up your workload. For example:

reproduce first the subfigure showing the expression profile of IL1A,
create a function from the previous code that takes as input the name of the gene and outputs the figure,
create subpanels B and C with patchwork,
work on the complex heatmap,
combine everything in one big panel.

Write your comments describing your work in an R Mardown document, breaking down the steps.
At the end of the day, present your work: what you achieved, where you had difficulties, the questions you had. At the end of the day, we will show you our version and discuss.

title: Workshop: reproduce a complex panelled figure
text:
Detailed instructions
Work in groups of 3–4.
Start with each subfigure individually to break up your workload. For example:

create a project,
save the dataset (located here) in the project’s folder and load it in the environment,
reproduce first the subfigure showing the expression profile of IL1A with ggplot2,
create a function from the previous code that takes as input the name of the gene and outputs the figure,
create subpanels B and C with patchwork,
work on reproducing the heatmap with ComplexHeatmap,
combine everything in one big panel.

Write your comments describing your work in an R Mardown document, with an HTML output, breaking down the steps.
At the end of the day, present your work: what you achieved, where you had difficulties, the questions you had. We will show you our own version.

title: Workshop: reproduce a complex panelled figure
text:
Learning objectives
By the end of this session, you should be able to: 1. Produce longitudinal gene-expression plots with ggplot2. 2. Write a reusable plotting function (input: gene name; output: a publication-style plot). 3. Assemble multi-panel figures using patchwork. 4. (Optional) Generate an annotated heatmap with appropriate scaling and clustering.

title: Workshop: reproduce a complex panelled figure
text:
Deliverables
Submit a rendered HTML report containing: - A short description of your approach (what you tried first, what you changed, why). - Your final plots (at least one complete subfigure). - A brief “Reflection” section: successes, difficulties, open questions.

title: Workshop: reproduce a complex panelled figure
text:
Team workflow
Work in groups of 3–4. Suggested roles: - Data wrangler (tidy dataset, checks, joins) - Plot developer (ggplot + theme + legends) - Integrator (functions + patchwork + final layout) - Reporter (narrative + reproducibility + final knit)

title: Workshop: reproduce a complex panelled figure
text:
Tasks and milestones

Milestone 1 — Start small (mandatory)
Reproduce one time-course plot (e.g., IL1A) with: - x-axis: days post illness onset - y-axis: normalized log2 counts - one line per case (1/2/3), with points


Milestone 2 — Generalize (mandatory)
Turn your code into a function, e.g. plot_gene_timecourse(gene_name).


Milestone 3 — Build panels B and C (recommended)
Use your function to generate the full set of genes shown in panels B and C, and assemble them with patchwork.


Milestone 4 — Heatmap (stretch goal)
Reproduce panel A: - row-wise scaling (z-score) and clustering - sample annotations (healthy controls vs cases; day from onset) - clearly labeled color scale

title: Workshop: reproduce a complex panelled figure
text:
Reporting guidelines
Your report should be structured and readable. Suggested sections: - Methods (data processing, scaling choices, plotting choices) - Results (final figures + short interpretation) - Reflection (what worked, what didn’t, what you would improve next)
